ALLEGATION:
It was alleged that a foster care worker failed to follow court orders and
allowed foster child A to spend unsupervised visit with her biological father.
2

INVESTIGATION:
 The complainant reported that over the course of the ongoing case involving
the foster child A placed in their home, the employees at Growing Hope
Through Love have provided little oversight and failed to follow Court orders
on her case. It was reported that the primary caseworker failed to read Court
orders resulting in the foster child participating in overnight visits with her
homeless father despite Court orders directing otherwise. The complainant
alleged that the case worker has consistently failed to address the
homelessness of the foster child's father or to adequately document agency
concerns.
 It is noted that the former caseworker no longer works for Growing Hope
Through Love however, she was available via by telephone.
An interview was held with the director of the program via email, onsite and
telephone. She reported she acknowledge the seriousness and the concerns of
the complainant. She reported that the allegation possible stems from concern of
reunification of the foster child with her biological father. The director reported
the case has been going on since 2017 with reunification being the goal. She
reported that the father had a lack of progress made within policy required
timeframes therefore, at a permanency planning hearing held in December of
2018 the agency plan to file a supplemental petition and currently the agency is
in the process of trial of the case.
This consultant reviewed the court reports for foster child A regarding the
allegation.
 Court order dated 10/04/2017 in summary states the court report and
testimony indicated the father is compliant with court ordered services.
The court order states the father’s home was assessed and deemed
suitable. The court ordered the recommendation allowing the worker
discretion for unsupervised visits for the father.
 Court order dated 12/18/17 in summary states the father is back in
compliant with the court ordered services. The father previously missed a
month of parenting time visits. Father is back employed due to
attendance problem created by attending parenting time visits. Supportive
visitation is pending and he is at the top of the waiting list. Father is not
attending doctor appointments due to the appointments being in another
county over an hour away. The agency provides bus tickets and gas
cards. The court continued the recommendation allowing the worker
discretion for unsupervised visits.
 Court order dated 03/26/2018 in summary states the court report and
testimony indicated the father has had several unsupervised visits in
January and February 2018 with the first unsupervised visit occurring on
12/29/2017. The court order states the father was arrested on 10/18/17
3

with the birth mom (Rights terminated) and that he received a citation.
The agency had concerns regarding the father’s continued association
with the birth mom. As a result of the agency concern, the assigned
caseworker has resumed supervised visits with the father. All prior orders
are continued except where modified.
 Court order dated 06/04/2018 in summary states the father is ordered
supervised visits by DHHS and or its designee. The court report
testimony indicated the father is partially compliant. The father has
appropriate housing, due to the distance from his residence and place of
employment, he does not stay at the home daily. All prior orders are
continued except where modified.
 Court order dated 08/15/2018 in summary adopted the recommendation
allowing the assigned caseworker desecration for unsupervised visits up
to and including overnights for the father once the home had been
assessed and deemed appropriate. All prior orders are continued except
where modified.
 The court orders per testimony/court reports, the foster child updated
service plans and parent agency treatment agreements all detailed the
biological father progress in meeting the requirements being in compliance
with the agency and courts recommendations as well as what he needed
to improve upon/barriers for reunification of foster child A.
The director reported that the agency caseworker believed that the agency still
had discretion for unsupervised visits as it had been their discretion since
10/04/2018. She reported beginning of June 2018 discussion planning towards
unsupervised visits began as the father was doing well with his parent agency
treatment plan. The director reported an unsupervised visit occurred on
06/24/2018. She reported overnights visits occurred on 06/30/18 -07/01/18,
07/11/18 – 07/12/18 and 07/14/18 -7/15/18. She reported a day visit occurred on
07/21/18. She said the agency unfortunately made an error of the overnight
visits despite the court order directing otherwise. This information was in the
court order that occurred on 03/26/2018. The director reported the agency went
back to supervised visit on 07/29/2018 once they realize their error. The director
reported the error was immediately communicated to the father of the child and
the foster parents.
The director reported an email and telephone call was made to the AG and Gal
on the child’s case explaining the error on how it was addressed and rectified.
She said all parties were understanding. She said a court hearing was held on
08/15/2018 and the error was discussed in court and it appeared that the courts
was understanding of the situation. A court hearing took place on 08/15/2018, the
court order then stated, “The Court adopted the recommendation allowing the
assigned caseworker discretion for unsupervised visits up to and including
overnights for the father once the home had been assessed and deemed
appropriate.
4

This Consultant reviewed the updated service plans between 03/07/18 –
05/31/18 and 06/01/18 – 08/29/2018. It was noted that foster child A had the
same caseworker from the agency and there was no staff changes during this
time frame.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12402 Program statement.
An agency shall have and follow a current written program
statement that includes all of the following information:
(c) Types of services provided to foster children and
their families.
ANALYSIS: The court order dated 03/26/2018 stated as a result of the
agency concern, the assigned caseworker has resumed
supervised visits with the father. All prior orders are continued
except where modified. It appeared that the agency did not
resume supervised visits between the father and foster child A.
Foster Child A was allowed to spend three overnight visits
without supervision and one day visit. The agency recognized
their mistake and immediately notified all parties admitting their
mistake. This consultant recognized that human errors exist.
The agency director reported the agency resumed supervised
visits on 07/29/2018; however, it was not reported what
action/steps were put in place to avoid this type of
action/measure from occurring in the future. The agency is
found in violation of not following the court order of supervised
visits between the father and foster child A between the dates of
06/30/18 -07/01/18, 07/11/18 – 07/12/18, 07/14/18 -7/15/18 and
06/04/18.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon completion of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend that Growing
Hope Through Love license remains unchanged.
